Issues.Title: Injector does not respect TypeScript type-only imports
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Description TypeScript introduced [type-only imports in version 3.8](https://www.typescriptlang.org/docs/handbook/release-notes/typescript-3-8.html#type-only-imports-and-exports) which contains the following text in the documentation: > `import type` only imports declarations to be used for type annotations and declarations. **It always gets fully erased, so there‚Äôs no remnant of it at runtime**. Now consider a new Angular CLI project with the following relevant files: **foo.ts**: ```ts console.log('I do not expect this statement to print if the file is imported as type-only.') export class Foo { } ``` **foo.token.ts**: ```ts import { InjectionToken } from '@angular/core'; export const FOO = new InjectionToken('Foo', { factory: () => { }; }); ``` **app.component.ts**: ```ts import { Component, Inject } from '@angular/core'; import { FOO } from './foo.token'; import type { Foo } from './foo'; @Component({ ... }) export class AppComponent { constructor(@Inject(FOO) foo: Foo) {} } ``` The key things to note is that the `Foo` class is being imported as a type only. It is also not being imported anywhere else in the project. As the `console.log` message in the `foo.ts` file states, I do not expect that line to print at run time. I do not expect that line to print because TypeScript says that type-only imports "always gets fully erased, so there‚Äôs no remnant of it at runtime". The actual behavior does not match my expected behavior because the `console.log` message is being printed at runtime. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction [StackBlitz](https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-54e8de) or [GitHub repo](https://github.com/samherrmann/angular-sandbox/commit/9c77f6a57b2c7d2bc036700d0df278232ef0a314) Observe the console. ## üåç Your Environment **Angular Version:** 


Angular CLI: 10.0.0
Node: 12.15.0
OS: linux x64

Angular: 10.0.2
... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms
... language-service, platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic
... router
Ivy Workspace: Yes

Package                           Version
-----------------------------------------------------------
@angular-devkit/architect         0.1000.0
@angular-devkit/build-angular     0.1000.0
@angular-devkit/build-optimizer   0.1000.0
@angular-devkit/build-webpack     0.1000.0
@angular-devkit/core              10.0.0
@angular-devkit/schematics        10.0.0
@angular/cli                      10.0.0
@ngtools/webpack                  10.0.0
@schematics/angular               10.0.0
@schematics/update                0.1000.0
rxjs                              6.5.5
typescript                        3.9.5
webpack                           4.43.0

Issues.Title: build(docs-infra): improve applying post-install patches
Issues.Body:
In `aio/`, we have a mechanism to apply patches in a `postinstall` hook. See `aio/tools/cli-patches/README.md` for more info.

Previously, we had to update `aio/tools/cli-patches/patch.js` to list each `.patch` file separately. While working on #37688, I found it helpful for the script to automatically pick up `.patch` files.

This commit updates the script to automatically pick up and apply `.patch` files from the `aio/tools/cli-patches/` directory. If one wants to keep a `.patch` file but not apply it, they can change the file's extension or move it to a sub-directory (without having to update the script).
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build(docs-infra): improve applying post-install patches" (#37896)

# üêû bug report

### Affected Package
<!-- Can you pin-point one or more @angular/* packages as the source of the bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: --> The issue is caused by package @angular/animations


### Is this a regression?

<!-- Did this behavior use to work in the previous version? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è--> Yes, without ivy animation events don't removed.


### Description

<!-- ‚úçÔ∏è-->
Animation events is removed from `AnimationTransitionNamespace` during change node's position inside `ViewContainerRef`. This causes issue inside `mat-tab-group` when tab's order is changed because displaying content depends on animation events.
When node's index is changed a node detaches from old position and inserts into new one. During detach animation events are removed, but not added when node inserts back into new position. 

## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
<!--
Please create and share minimal reproduction of the issue starting with this template: https://stackblitz.com/fork/angular-ivy
-->

#### Steps to reproduce:
1. Open StackBlitz
2. Enable Ivy in settings
3. Click on rearrange button
4. Click on Tab 2. There is no content.

Issues.Title: test: fix test failure in saucelabs ivy ie10
Issues.Body:
One of the ivy acceptance tests currently fails in IE10. This is because we
recently added a new test that asserts that injecting `ViewRef` results in
a `NullInjectorError`.

Due to limitations in TypeScript and in polyfills for `setPrototypeOf`, the error
cannot be thrown as `ViewRef` is always considered injectable. In reality, `ViewRef`
should not be injectable, as explicitly noted in https://github.com/angular/angular/commit/c00f4ab2ae703e8a3ee4a3850170c9bbf0f9bc42.

There seems no way to simulate the proper prototype chain in such browsers
that do not natively support `__proto__`, so TypeScript and `core-js` polyfills
simply break the prototype chain and assign inherited properties directly
on `ViewRef`. i.e. so that `ViewRef.__NG_ELEMENT_ID__` exists and DI picks it up.

There is a way for TypeScript to theoretically generate proper prototype chain in
ES5 output, but they intend to only bother about the proper prototype chain in ES6
where `setPrototypeOf` etc. are officially standardized. See the response: https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript/issues/1601#issuecomment-94892833.


I have a feeling  that it's better keeping the `hasOwnProperty` logic (as added with c00f4ab2ae703e8a3ee4a3850170c9bbf0f9bc42),
as IE10 will not fail but rather just be less strict. At the same time though, it could also
be an option to just enforce consistency by reverting your fix. Either way seems not 100%
ideal. I assume it's a conceptual issue with how `__NG_ELEMENT_ID` is handled.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "test: fix test failure in saucelabs ivy ie10" (#37892)

Issues.Title: fix(dev-infra): include `bazel` utility files in npm package
Issues.Body:
We recently added a new folder for common bazel utilties
to `dev-infra`. The `ng_rollup_bundle` rule relies on an
utility that is provided by this `bazel/` folder.

Unfortunately though it looks like this folder is currently
not included in the NPM package, so that the `ng_rollup_bundle`
rule does not work as expected. This commit fixes that by
including the bazel utilties in the NPM package.

Issues.Title: feat(dev-infra): merge script should link to original commit when cherry-picking with API strategy
Issues.Body:
The merge script uses `git cherry-pick` for both the API merge strategy
and the autosquash strategy. It uses cherry-pick to push commits to
different target branches (e.g. into the `10.0.x` branch).

Those commits never point to the commits that landed in the primary
Github branch though. For the autosquash strategy the pull request number
is always included, so there is a way to go back to the source. On the other
hand though, for commits cherry-picked in the API merge strategy, the
pull request number might not always be included (due to Github's
implementation of the rebase merge method).

e.g. https://github.com/angular/components/commit/27f52711c0618a9ae4eab4c888c8ab3245638e77

For those cases we'd want to link the cherry-picked commits to the
original commits so that the corresponding PR is easier to track
down. This is not needed for the autosquash strategy (as outlined
before), but it would have been good for consistency. Unfortunately
though this would rather complicate the strategy as the autosquash
strategy cherry-picks directly from the PR head, so the SHAs that
are used in the primary branch are not known.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(dev-infra): merge script should link to original commit when cherry-picking with API strategy" (#37889)

Issues.Title: ngcc: unable to process libary
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package @angular/cli || ngcc || ng-package ### Is this a regression? Worked with Angular 9 (IVY enabled) ### Description When updating our project to Angular 10 we are unable to build the library that manages general UI components for our company (https://github.com/porscheinformatik/material-addons). ngcc fails to compile angular material Components for our project and that in turn then leads the build tobe unable to resolve our Components. ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction git clone https://github.com/chrisaige/angular-ivy-example npm i -> should display the ngcc errors ng serve example --prod -> should display that compontens from "porscheinformatik/material-addons" are missing ## üî• Exception or Error Thats what the ngcc spits out when you run an npm i 

Error: Failed to compile entry-point @porscheinformatik/material-addons (esm2015 as esm2015) due to compilation errors:
node_modules/@porscheinformatik/material-addons/node_modules/@angular/material/menu/menu-module.d.ts:14:22 - error NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of ToolbarModule, but could not be resolved to an NgModule class.

This likely means that the library (@angular/material/menu) which declares MatMenuModule has not been processed correctly by ngcc, or is not compatible with Angular Ivy. Check if a newer version of the library is available, and upda
te if so. Also consider checking with the library's authors to see if the library is expected to be compatible with Ivy.

14 export declare class MatMenuModule {
                        ~~~~~~~~~~~~~
node_modules/@porscheinformatik/material-addons/node_modules/@angular/material/toolbar/toolbar-module.d.ts:8:22 - error NG6002: Appears in the NgModule.imports of ToolbarModule, but could not be resolved to an NgModule class.

This likely means that the library (@angular/material/toolbar) which declares MatToolbarModule has not been processed correctly by ngcc, or is not compatible with Angular Ivy. Check if a newer version of the library is available, an
d update if so. Also consider checking with the library's authors to see if the library is expected to be compatible with Ivy.

8 export declare class MatToolbarModule {
                       ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
node_modules/@porscheinformatik/material-addons/esm2015/lib/toolbar/toolbar.module.js:11:14 - error NG6003: Appears in the NgModule.exports of MaterialAddonsModule, but itself has errors

11 export class ToolbarModule {
                ~~~~~~~~~~~~~

Compiling @angular/material/datepicker : esm2015 as esm2015
**Anything else relevant?** Currently I have IVY disabled, so I could complete the update to Angular 10, but it would be nice to get this resolved, is it a problem with our library?

Issues.Title: refactor(forms): store raw validators in addition to combined validators function
Issues.Body:
NOTE: this is an **experimental** PR to test how we can store original list of validators and check whether such change would be compatible with existing apps in Google's codebase.

This commit refactors the way we store validators in AbstractControl-based classes: in addition to the combined validators function that we have, we also store the original list of validators. This is needed to have an ability to clean then up later at destroy time (currently it's problematic since they are combined in a single function) to avoid memory leaks.

Issues.Title: Automatically reduce number of placeholder comment nodes for ngIf and ngSwitch
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Relevant Package
https://github.com/angular/angular/blob/master/packages/common/src/directives/ng_switch.ts


### Description

When using ngIf or ngSwitch the framework adds comment nodes to the DOM that act as placeholders. This can become a performance issue, for example with a large switch block (50 cases) inside a component that is repeated many times (1000+). Each inactive switch case has a placeholder comment node for each 

In some manual tests I did, the chrome memory profiler showed that there were > 13000 comment nodes, and most of them were from a single ngSwitch inside a table cell component (I tested this by removing all the cells). This accounted for over 4% of total memory consumption in a large app. According to a theory of mine this will also slow down other actions on the page due to the increased DOM size which decreases the cache locality of non-comment elements.


### Describe the solution you'd like

I have a theory that the framework can automatically skip creating comment nodes that are unnecessary. For ngSwitch, no comment nodes should be necessary if there are no "interleaved" elements or text content between the switch cases. If there is only one "interleaved" thing, then only one comment node should be necessary to keep track of the location of the inactive group of cases.

The same trick should also work for ngIf, with the caveat that we still need placeholder comment nodes unless the compiler knows that the if blocks are mutually exclusive, and also they don't have content between them.

I hope this makes sense, but please let me know if I can clarify anything. I'm sure there are other good solutions too, so I would like to start some brainstorming.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Automatically reduce number of placeholder comment nodes for ngIf and ngSwitch" (#37880)

Issues.Title: refactor(core): remove unused fakeAsyncFallback and asyncFallback
Issues.Body:
`zone.js` 0.8.25 introduces `zone-testing` bundle and move all `fakeAsync/async` logic
from `@angular/core/testing` to `zone.js` package. But in case some user still using the old
version of `zone.js`, an old version of `fakeAsync/async` logic were still kept inside `@angular/core/testing`
package as `fallback` logic. Since now `Angular8+` already use `zone.js 0.9+`, so
those fallback logic can be removed.

# üêû bug description I have issues in Angular 10 with the sanitation of URLs on Background-images on DIV-elements. On a regular IMG tag the sanitation works. Issues.Title: Failed to set the 'responseType' property on 'XMLHttpRequest'
Issues.Body:
# üêû bug report ### Affected Package The issue is caused by package @angular/http ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version might have had this bug. I can see this being discussed by people in 2018 on Stackoverflow. ### Description From the research that I did, this seems to happening if one of the JS assets on your page is making a synchronous request. Sometimes, a tracking library included on the page is making synchronous calls and is messing up with the angular HTTP requests. You can find related questions here: - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49666138/not-able-to-use-httpclient-in-angular-5/52158459#comment110802776_52158459 - https://stackoverflow.com/questions/49048060/subscribing-to-httpclient-get-method-results-in-an-xmlhttprequest-error/62656061#62656061 ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction For minimal reproduction, please refer to the repo here: https://github.com/haseebahmed7/angular-bugrepro-37875 ## üî• Exception or Error

Issues.Title: Give Universal project more love
Issues.Body:
Hi,

prerendering and dynamic server-side rendering is essential feature in today B2C sites.

The continuing feature of Angular Universal is that there is almost no documentation.

There used to be a showcase repo [universal-starter](https://github.com/angular/universal-starter) that allowed us to see how the prerendering was done (despite not documented at the time). This repo is now archived.

We are currently stuck with Angular 8, because there is no documentation, how to upgrade the prerender / SSR logic from existing solution. This is especially painful in more complicated scenarios, such as dynamic routes generation preceding prerendering phase.

When competing with React and Vue, Universal should be showcased as first class citizen. Instead, it mostly seem like unwanted cousin.

Please, give Angular Universal more love.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Give Universal project more love" (#37871)

Issues.Title: For the benefit of new users, please emit an error for `*ngFor="let b in a"` instead of `*ngFor="let b of a"`
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

### Description
I've repeatedly experienced inconvenience with the expression format `*ngFor="for ... in ..."`. Each time, I have had to take the penalty of a full build of my whole project folder before I noticed the issue.  Please fail the build sooner; I have to imagine this impacts new users even more often.

### Describe the solution you'd like
In AOT, emit an error.  In my project, no error is emitted before runtime.

### Describe alternatives you've considered
This is a request for new users.

Issues.Title: build: update puppeteer to version 5.0.0
Issues.Body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [puppeteer](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer) | devDependencies | major | [`4.0.1` -> `5.0.0`](https://renovatebot.com/diffs/npm/puppeteer/4.0.1/5.0.0) |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>puppeteer/puppeteer</summary>

### [`v5.0.0`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/releases/v5.0.0)

[Compare Source](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/compare/v4.0.1...v5.0.0)

#### Breaking changes

##### Removal of `page.emulateMedia` ([#​6084](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6084))

This method was deprecated and is now removed from Puppeteer. Swap to `page.emulateMediaType` which behaves identically.

##### Removal of `require('puppeteer/DeviceDescriptors')` ([#​6043](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6043))

This top level file has been removed from the Puppeteer package. The same data is exposed via `puppeteer.devices`, so swap to that:

```js
// before
const devices = require('puppeteer/DeviceDescriptors');

// after
const puppeteer = require('puppeteer');
const devices = puppeteer.devices
```

##### Removal of `require('puppeteer/Errors')` ([#​6043](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6043))

This top level file has been removed from the Puppeteer package. The same data is exposed via `puppeteer.errors`, so swap to that:

```js
// before
const errors = require('puppeteer/Errors');

// after
const puppeteer = require('puppeteer');
const errors = puppeteer.errors
```

#### Behind the scenes

-   We've continued our drive to migrate to a new documentation system using TSDoc. These docs are available in the [`new-docs`](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/blob/main/new-docs/puppeteer.md) directory on GitHub. These aren't ready for use just yet but we're making great progress. You can track this work in [#​6118](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6118). 

-   We've continued improving our TypeScript definitions. Our tests are now migrated to TypeScript ([#​5830](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/5830)) so that we're consuming our own API. Work continues to ship built-in type definitions in a future version. You can track this work in [#​6124](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6124).

-   We've started restructuring Puppeteer to work towards being able to better support an environment agnostic Puppeteer module. You can track this work in [#​6125](https://togithub.com/puppeteer/puppeteer/issues/6125).

Issues.Title: Automatic upgrade of the global variants of the locale data
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [x] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
In Angular 9 and earlier the recommended use of the global variants of the locale data was as following:

```ts
import { registerLocaleData } from '@angular/common';

import localeFr from '@angular/common/locales/fr';
import localeDe from '@angular/common/locales/de';

registerLocaleData(localeFr);
registerLocaleData(localeDe);
```

With Angular 10 there's a new way (and a breaking change):

```ts
import '@angular/common/locales/global/fr';
import '@angular/common/locales/de';
```


### Describe the solution you'd like

- Given it's a breaking change, provide an automatic upgrade support from the Angular 9 to Angular 10.
- Provide information about this breaking change in the Update tool (https://update.angular.io/)


### Describe alternatives you've considered

The only alternative is to manually upgrade the code and to inform the customers about breaking changes (for the lib authors)
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Automatic upgrade of the global variants of the locale data" (#18123)

Issues.Title: ng build in docker failing after migrating from Angular 7 to 8
Issues.Body:
We upgraded Angular from 7 to 8.

But while building the docker image this step is failing:

```
ng "build" "--prod" "--configuration" "development" "--output-path=docs" "--serviceWorker=true" "--verbose" "--progress=true"
```

Is getting stucked at 11% with this stacktrace:

```
[webpack.Progress] 11% building 11/12 modules 1 active /app-ui/node_modules/mini-css-extract-plugin/dist/loader.js!/app-ui/node_modules/@angular-devkit/build-angular/src/angular-cli-files/plugins/raw-css-loader.js!/app-ui/node_modules/postcss-loader/src/index.js??extracted!/app-ui/node_modules/sass-loader/lib/loader.js??ref--15-3!/app-ui/src/styles.scss
Removing intermediate container e45e8a69a2aa
Then failed to copy a directory in docker:

Step 14/16 : COPY --from=0 /app-ui/docs /usr/share/nginx/html
COPY failed: stat /var/lib/docker/overlay2/***/merged/app-ui/docs: no such file or directory
```

Here's my Dockerfile:

```
FROM node:12.10.0-alpine

ENV LC_ALL C

ARG env=production

RUN apk update && apk upgrade && apk add --no-cache make git && rm -rf /var/cache/apk/* /tmp/*

ADD . /app-ui
WORKDIR /app-ui

RUN npm install
RUN npm run ng build -- --prod --configuration $env --output-path=docs --serviceWorker=true --verbose --progress=true

FROM nginx:alpine

RUN apk update && apk upgrade && rm -rf /var/cache/apk/* /tmp/*
RUN rm -rf /usr/share/nginx/html/*
COPY nginx.conf /etc/nginx/nginx.conf

COPY --from=0 /app-ui/docs /usr/share/nginx/html

EXPOSE 80
CMD ["nginx", "-g", "daemon off;"]
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "ng build in docker failing after migrating from Angular 7 to 8" (#18121)

Issues.Title: 93% after chunk asset optimization SourceMapDevToolPlugin main.1b9b59268b1b5cce43d3.esm.js generate SourceMap
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report ### Command (mark with an `x`) - [x] build ### Is this a regression? Yes, the previous version in which this bug was not present was: .... I can see two issues closed and locked in the past. However it seems different this time. 1. This one was related to serve command and the solution was `ng serve --sourcemap=false` https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/5775 2. This one seems to be related to uglifyjs-webpack-plugin, but now angular-cli uses terser. https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/13005 ### Description I'm using `@nrwl/nx` to build a normal react app. I found once I `open the sourceMap: true flag` and `import some uglified library`, the production build stucks. ```js config.optimization.minimizer: [ TerserPlugin { options: { test: /\.m?js(\?.*)?$/i, chunkFilter: [Function: chunkFilter], warningsFilter: [Function: warningsFilter], extractComments: true, sourceMap: true, cache: true, cacheKeys: [Function: cacheKeys], parallel: true, include: undefined, exclude: undefined, minify: undefined, terserOptions: [Object] } }, HashedModuleIdsPlugin { options: { context: null, hashFunction: 'md4', hashDigest: 'base64', hashDigestLength: 4 } }, BundleBudgetPlugin { options: { budgets: [Array] } }, CleanCssWebpackPlugin { _options: { sourceMap: true, test: [Function: test] } }, TerserPlugin { options: { test: /\.m?js(\?.*)?$/i, chunkFilter: [Function: chunkFilter], warningsFilter: [Function: warningsFilter], extractComments: true, sourceMap: true, cache: true, cacheKeys: [Function: cacheKeys], parallel: true, include: undefined, exclude: undefined, minify: undefined, terserOptions: [Object] } }, TerserPlugin { options: { test: /\.m?js(\?.*)?$/i, chunkFilter: [Function: chunkFilter], warningsFilter: [Function: warningsFilter], extractComments: true, sourceMap: true, cache: true, cacheKeys: [Function: cacheKeys], parallel: true, include: undefined, exclude: undefined, minify: undefined, terserOptions: [Object] } } ] Starting type checking service... Using 6 workers with 8192MB memory limit 93% after chunk asset optimization SourceMapDevToolPlugin main.40bf8eeaca32ae9b3f36.esm.js generate SourceMap ``` I did some research and found it's kind of weird in the `optimization.minimizer` option, **there're 3 TerserPlugins**: So I tried to remove the last two minimizers and it works. ```diff /* eslint-disable @typescript-eslint/no-var-requires */ const addReactConfiguration = require('@nrwl/react/plugins/webpack'); module.exports = (config, options) => { + config.optimization.minimizer.pop(); + config.optimization.minimizer.pop(); console.log('config.optimization.minimizer: ', config.optimization.minimizer) addReactConfiguration(config); return config; }; ``` Although it has a new warning, but it's better than stucking: ``` > nx run linda-ui:build-web:production --cache=false config, options: [ TerserPlugin { options: { test: /\.m?js(\?.*)?$/i, chunkFilter: [Function: chunkFilter], warningsFilter: [Function: warningsFilter], extractComments: true, sourceMap: true, cache: true, cacheKeys: [Function: cacheKeys], parallel: true, include: undefined, exclude: undefined, minify: undefined, terserOptions: [Object] } }, HashedModuleIdsPlugin { options: { context: null, hashFunction: 'md4', hashDigest: 'base64', hashDigestLength: 4 } }, BundleBudgetPlugin { options: { budgets: [Array] } }, CleanCssWebpackPlugin { _options: { sourceMap: true, test: [Function: test] } } ] config.optimization.minimizer: [ TerserPlugin { options: { test: /\.m?js(\?.*)?$/i, chunkFilter: [Function: chunkFilter], warningsFilter: [Function: warningsFilter], extractComments: true, sourceMap: true, cache: true, cacheKeys: [Function: cacheKeys], parallel: true, include: undefined, exclude: undefined, minify: undefined, terserOptions: [Object] } }, HashedModuleIdsPlugin { options: { context: null, hashFunction: 'md4', hashDigest: 'base64', hashDigestLength: 4 } }, BundleBudgetPlugin { options: { budgets: [Array] } }, CleanCssWebpackPlugin { _options: { sourceMap: true, test: [Function: test] } } ] Starting type checking service... Using 6 workers with 8192MB memory limit Hash: aeb17ff0a2df95f64057 Built at: 07/02/2020 5:02:18 PM Entrypoint main [big] = runtime.d141d7cd79d1c92ef9d4.js runtime.d141d7cd79d1c92ef9d4.js.map main.886af04f304a6e808a61.esm.js main.886af04f304a6e808a61.esm.js.map Entrypoint polyfills = runtime.d141d7cd79d1c92ef9d4.js runtime.d141d7cd79d1c92ef9d4.js.map polyfills.77fdf6ad8621940cf3f2.esm.js polyfills.77fdf6ad8621940cf3f2.esm.js.map chunk {0} runtime.d141d7cd79d1c92ef9d4.js, runtime.d141d7cd79d1c92ef9d4.js.map (runtime) 0 bytes ={1}= ={2}= [entry] [rendered] chunk {1} main.886af04f304a6e808a61.esm.js, main.886af04f304a6e808a61.esm.js.map (main) 4.99 MiB ={0}= [initial] [rendered] chunk {2} polyfills.77fdf6ad8621940cf3f2.esm.js, polyfills.77fdf6ad8621940cf3f2.esm.js.map (polyfills) 239 KiB ={0}= [initial] [rendered] WARNING in budgets, maximum exceeded for initial. Budget 2 MB was exceeded by 657 kB. Starting type checking service... Using 6 workers with 8192MB memory limit Hash: aa9389010c94cd24b861 Built at: 07/02/2020 5:02:45 PM Entrypoint main [big] = runtime.4032bbce286bbd727cde.js runtime.4032bbce286bbd727cde.js.map main.c64bd22f0b27ecdf72e2.es5.js main.c64bd22f0b27ecdf72e2.es5.js.map Entrypoint polyfills = runtime.4032bbce286bbd727cde.js runtime.4032bbce286bbd727cde.js.map polyfills.10361f33259115e3f3f6.es5.js polyfills.10361f33259115e3f3f6.es5.js.map chunk {0} runtime.4032bbce286bbd727cde.js, runtime.4032bbce286bbd727cde.js.map (runtime) 0 bytes ={1}= ={2}= [entry] [rendered] chunk {1} main.c64bd22f0b27ecdf72e2.es5.js, main.c64bd22f0b27ecdf72e2.es5.js.map (main) 4.99 MiB ={0}= [initial] [rendered] chunk {2} polyfills.10361f33259115e3f3f6.es5.js, polyfills.10361f33259115e3f3f6.es5.js.map (polyfills) 388 KiB ={0}= [initial] [rendered] WARNING in budgets, maximum exceeded for initial. Budget 2 MB was exceeded by 706 kB. ``` A clear and concise description of the problem... ## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction ## üî• Exception or Error no errors ## üåç Your Environment

Issues.Title: ng build error TS6059 does not explain where error is happening
Issues.Body:
<!--üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ

Oh hi there! üòÑ

To expedite issue processing please search open and closed issues before submitting a new one.
Existing issues often contain information about workarounds, resolution, or progress updates.

üîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖüîÖ-->


# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are relevant for this feature request? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->
- [ ] new
- [x] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test
- [ ] e2e
- [ ] generate
- [ ] add
- [ ] update
- [ ] lint
- [ ] xi18n
- [ ] run
- [ ] config
- [ ] help
- [ ] version
- [ ] doc

### Description
I'm not sure if this is an error with ng-cli or with typescript itself, if it's typescript problem I will happily transfer the issue to them!


I was just building an ng library, which had some errors, but the message shown is not every helpful actually. See the following:

```
[error] Error: error TS6059: File '/work/trading-bots/trading-bots-panel/src/app/consts.ts' is not under 'rootDir' '/work/trading-bots/trading-bots-panel/projects/hotkeys/src'. 'rootDir' is expected to contain all source files.
error TS6059: File '/work/trading-bots/trading-bots-panel/src/app/translations.module.ts' is not under 'rootDir' '/work/trading-bots/trading-bots-panel/projects/hotkeys/src'. 'rootDir' is expected to contain all source files.
error TS6059: File '/work/trading-bots/trading-bots-panel/src/app/utils.ts' is not under 'rootDir' '/work/trading-bots/trading-bots-panel/projects/hotkeys/src'. 'rootDir' is expected to contain all source files.
```

I get that the issue is I'm referencing a file that is outside the root folder of the library, the problem I see is that the error does not explain in which file this file is referenced from.



### Describe the solution you'd like
Solution would be, if possible, to add the file where this error happened!


### Describe alternatives you've considered
I haven't found any workaround nor have I been able to pinpoint where the error is.

Issues.Title: build: update validate-commits script to tell us valid scopes
Issues.Body:
The commit linter expects a certain scope in the commit message,
but if the right scope is not provided it doesn't tell us what to do.

Instead of this:
```
The following commit has an unknown type. You can use wip: to avoid this.
```

It now outputs this:
```
The following commit has an unknown type. It must be one of [docs, refactor, style, test, feat, fix, build, revert, ci, release]. You can use wip: to avoid this.
```

Issues.Title: Improve documentation for major release
Issues.Body:
This PR documents some of the learnings from the recent v10.0.0 release.
Our release doc does not sufficiently capture the process of a major release, and our tooling is insufficient to support the workflow.

There are two commits:

# üöÄ Feature request


### Command (mark with an `x`)

- [ ] new
- [ ] build
- [ ] serve
- [ ] test

### Description

This might be a controversial opinion, but It seems odd to me that a compiler/bundler/linter would be opinionated about my version control status, or even my choice of VCS. I'd argue that angular cli should be agnostic about my git status.

Issues.Title: Use TSConfig bases in npm to reduce the number of TSConfigs in a project
Issues.Body:
# üöÄ feature request

:wave: - hi folks. I got notified that we could probably improve the default template for an angular project using the tsconfig bases repo. A. quick 5m explainer on [the project is here](https://github.com/microsoft/TypeScript-Website/issues/130#issuecomment-652399262). 

Disclaimer: I've never built an Angular app, so some of this is from looking at the base template, and I'm not sure how tsconfig's would evolve over time in large projects.

### Relevant Package

`ng generate`'s template

### Description

TSConfig files can come from NPM, and [TSConfig Bases](https://github.com/tsconfig/bases/) is a DefinitelyTyped-like tool for making them. Today, there are a few recommended bases for frameworks (svelte, react-native, deno etc) and given there are a few angular TSConfigs then I think it could be possible to move them into node_modules. 

So for example there could be 

- `@tsconfig/angular-base` 
- `@tsconfig/angular-test`  

Which the user's projects can extend from.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Use TSConfig bases in npm to reduce the number of TSConfigs in a project" (#18101)

Issues.Title: externalSchematic doesn't work for globally installed nested dependencies
Issues.Body:
# üêû Bug report

### Command (mark with an `x`)
<!-- Can you pin-point the command or commands that are effected by this bug? -->
<!-- ‚úçÔ∏èedit: -->

- [x] new
- [ ] build

- [ ] doc


### Is this a regression?

Yes, this previously worked in v8


### Description

Using "externalSchematic" on a collection defined in a dependency of a custom schematic, does not work when the custom schematic is installed globally. Globally installed npm packages are not flattened/deduped and the nested collection dependency is not found by "externalSchematic".


## üî¨ Minimal Reproduction
Running `ng new -c schematic-1`. 

"schematic-1" is installed globally (`npm i schematic-1 -g`) and has an npm dependency on "schematic-2". 

Under the global node_modules folder, "schematic-1" has a nested node_modules folder containing "schematic-2". If installed locally, npm will flatten the dependencies and "schematic-1" and "schematic-2" will be siblings, but a global install will nest "schematic-2" under "schematic-1".

"schematic-1" calls `externalSchematic('schematic-2', 'ng-add', options),` from `ng new`.

When installed globally, this fails with "Collection schematic-2 cannot be resolved" When installed locally, and dependencies are flatted, this succeeds.

## üî• Exception or Error
Collection schematic-2 cannot be resolved


## üåç Your Environment
Angular CLI: 9.1.9
Node: 10.21.0
OS: darwin x64

Issues.Title: bug(MatSidenav): Overlay scroll strategies do not work in sidenavs and drawers.
Issues.Body:
#### Reproduction

https://stackblitz.com/edit/angular-ivy-ng8reg?file=src%2Fapp%2Fapp.component.ts

Steps to reproduce:
1. Utilize an overlay or a component with an overlay in a mat-sidenav or mat-drawer that overflows.
2. Declare cdkScrollable on the sidenav or drawer.
3. Scroll the sidenav or drawer.
 
#### Expected Behavior

The overlay's scroll strategy is honored (e.g. the overlay remains fixed to its origin).

#### Actual Behavior

The sidenav's inner container, .mat-drawer-inner-container, handles the overflow and scrolls. Therefore, the cdkScrollable directive has no effect and the scroll strategy is not honored.

#### Environment

- Angular: 10.0.2
- CDK/Material: 10.0.1
- Browser(s): Chrome 83.0.4103.116
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): macOS

#### Related Issues

- #10079 has many comments that are likely caused by this issue. However, it is specific to autocomplete while this issue affects all overlays.
- #8405 is the same issue for tabs.

#### Fix

CdkScrollable is [declared on mat-sidenav-content](https://github.com/angular/components/blob/master/src/material/sidenav/sidenav-container.html#L8) but not .mat-drawer-inner-container.

#### Workaround

Place the following in your global styles, and declare CdkScrollable on the mat-sidenav.
```sass
.mat-drawer, .mat-sidenav {
  &[cdk-scrollable], &[cdkScrollable] {
    .mat-drawer-inner-container {
      overflow: visible;
    }
  }
}
```
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatSidenav): Overlay scroll strategies do not work in sidenavs and drawers." (#19846)

Issues.Title: build: increase snapshot publish job queue confidence threshold
Issues.Body:
We recently added a new step to the snapshot publish job. The step will block
the job until all previous snapshot publish jobs that have been launched before
complete.

This step relies on the CircleCI API which does not always refresh immediately.
This means that we could run into a race condition where the queue does not
detect previous jobs. This has been observed with:

https://app.circleci.com/pipelines/github/angular/components/9618/workflows/52fef2b9-8059-4c00-8c2e-347b83ad1031/jobs/158528/steps

We fix this by increasing the confidence threshold of the queue step, so that
it will perform a second CircleCI request after a delay to avoid the race condition
in the most common cases. It's a trade-off between stability and delay. We could
certainly increase the threshold further, but that will slow down CI on publish
branches, so we start experimenting with lower threshold values first.

Overall this queue has been working quite well so far. just two potential race conditions that
should be fixed by this change.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: increase snapshot publish job queue confidence threshold" (#19843)

Issues.Title: build: ensure project version is set correctly in NPM package output
Issues.Body:
In framework, the version placeholder computation was incorrect
in some situations. i.e. the release packages used a version that
indicates local changes like `x.x.x-local-changes`. We should ensure
that the release output matches the expected version.

This is especially becoming relevant when we switch to a shared
Bazel workspace status command from the dev-infra package. The
workspace status command is responsible for determining the version
placeholder value when building with `--config=release`.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: ensure project version is set correctly in NPM package output" (#19841)

Issues.Title: build: remove workaround for decorator metadata in universal-app
Issues.Body:
In the past, Angular removed tsickle from the build pipeline. This meant
that decorators were not downleveled, and executed immediately. This
caused errors in SSR as parameters or input types are accessed on
file load as runtime values. e.g. consider an input that used
`HTMLElement` as type. The TypeScript decorator output would access
`HTMLElement` on file load directly. This breaks on the server as such
DOM specific globals do not exist there.

We worked around this by providing global mocks for these symbols. Now
with Angular v10 though, Angular processes decorators by default without
requiring tsickle. This means that we can remove the workaround.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "build: remove workaround for decorator metadata in universal-app" (#19840)

Issues.Title: bug([mat-table]): mat-tab-group messes up expandable rows in table
Issues.Body:
**Reproduction**
Stackblitz project: https://stackblitz.com/edit/github-itepdn
To see the bug, just open the app, switch to the second tab and go back to the first one.
The bug only shows with enabled Ivy compiler.

**Expected Behavior**
Switching tabs in `mat-tab-group` shouldn't affect the expanded rows in the table.

**Actual Behavior**
All rows in the table are expanded after switching to the second tab and back. This shouldn't be possible as normally the table allows only for one expanded row at a time.

**Environment**
- Angular: 9.1.0
- CDK/Material: 9.2.0
- Browser(s): Chrome
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows and Ubuntu
- **Enabled Ivy**

**Known workarounds**

- Disable Ivy
```
{
  ...
  "angularCompilerOptions": {
    "enableIvy": false,
    ...
  }
}

```

- Lazy load tab
```
    <mat-tab label="Table">
       <ng-template matTabContent>
         <app-table></app-table>
       </ng-template>
    </mat-tab>
```

Is there any other clean solution without disabling ivy or lazy loading tabs?
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug([mat-table]): mat-tab-group messes up expandable rows in table" (#19838)

Issues.Title: Provide lighter surface for dark themes elevations
Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Hi there ! First of all thanks for your amazing works on Angular and Angular components :).

Today I want to propose to enrich the current elevation API by providing lighter background color depending on elevation level just like it's exposed here [https://material.io/design/color/dark-theme.html#properties](https://material.io/design/color/dark-theme.html#properties). Of course it will be enabled only for dark themes.

Why this feature request ? Because some components like `mat-expansion-panel` are very hard to distinct inside a `mat-card` because they have the same background color. This problem is also present in light themes but there is no material recommandations for it. I'm not a design expert and I have no idea how to handle this. Suggestions are welcomed :)

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23034761/86342972-9cadc800-bc58-11ea-9a70-19c14cb9e0a0.png)

#### Use Case

It can be used with native `.mat-elevation-zX` class or with an additionnal class/mixin.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Provide lighter surface for dark themes elevations" (#19837)

Issues.Title: bug(datepicker): `calendar.selectedChange.emit` not working in v10 (regression?)
Issues.Body:
#### Intro

I have a custom datepicker that wraps material's datepicker and [adds a custom header](https://material.angular.io/components/datepicker/overview#customizing-the-calendar-header). This custom header provides some useful action buttons to set the date to the most typical needed dates for that use case; for example, a button to set it in a month from today.

This component was built in Angular Material 6-7 times and worked flawlessly till Angular Material 9. Upgrading to Material v10, though, made it stop working. The problem seems to be in `this.calendar.selectedChange.emit(theDateIWantToSet);` which doesn't update the input's date anymore. See minimal repro below.


#### Expected Behavior

1. Go to https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-qqxg7v (made with Angular 9)
2. Click in the icon to open the calendar.
3. Click in the `In a month` button.
4. See how the popup is closed and the date is updated (a month from today is added; August 2, 2020 in the time of writing this). This is the expected behavior.
 
 
#### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce the regression:
1. Go to https://stackblitz.com/edit/components-issue-tbqwwk (same code as before, but dependencies upgraded to Angular 10)
2. Click in the icon to open the calendar.
3. Click in the `In a month` button.
4. See how the popup is closed but **the date doesn't change**.


#### Actual Behavior

`this.calendar.selectedChange.emit(theDateIWantToSet);` doesn't change the date to `theDateIWantToSet`.


#### Environment

- Angular: any (working with both 9 and 10)
- CDK/Material: not working with 10, working with 9 and below
- Browser(s): any
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): any
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(datepicker): `calendar.selectedChange.emit` not working in v10 (regression?)" (#19836)

Issues.Body: #### Reproduction Use StackBlitz to reproduce your issue: https://stackblitz.com/fork/components-issue https://stackblitz.com/github/Marcusg62/angular-material-bug- Steps to reproduce: 1. ng new testapp 2. ng generate @angular/material:navigation shell 3. add `` to app.component.html 4. You can change the css so that you get the scrolling with hidden bars, but not the toolbar to be stikcy. #### Actual Behavior What behavior did you actually see? There is a css property `.sidenav-container { height: 100%; }` Which doesn't allow this feature to happen. If you comment out this `height: 100%; `, the feature takes affect but the toolbar is no longer sticky. So the key is to get a sticky/fixed mat-toolbar without side effects. I've tried doing things like `position: fixed` but that has a lot of bad side effects on positioning items inside the toolbar. #### Environment - Angular: 9.1.9 - CDK/Material: 8.2.4 - Browser(s): Mobile Safari 13.1 - Operating System iOS 13.4.1
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(mat-sidenav): Navigation Schematic - does not allow full screen scrolling on iOS devices" (#19835)

Issues.Title: fix(cdk/platform): rtl scroll axis incorrectly determined in Safari macOS
Issues.Body:
In Safari on macOS, the RTL scroll axis is determined incorrectly when
scrollbars are set to `Always Display` as per macOS general system
preferences. Our test element for the scroll axis sets a fixed height.

This is resulting in a vertical scroll bar as the horizontal scroll bar
for testing `scrollLeft` exceeds the scroll containers `1px` height. The
vertical scroll bar then unveils a bug in Webkit where space is acquired
on the right side for the scroll bar (while it's displayed on the left).

This space causes our scroll axis detection to break as the horizontal
`scrollLeft` unexpectedly expands to: `[-scrollWidth, 15px]` while
usually `0px` is the right boundary. We fix this by simply ensuring
that no vertical scroll bar is ever displayed. The vertical scrolling
is not needed for determining the RTL horizontal scroll axis type.

I've reported a bug upstream in Webkit:
https://bugs.webkit.org/show_bug.cgi?id=213851.

I tested manually on Chrome 83.0.4103.116 Windows 10; macOS High Sierra Firefox 77; macOS High Sierra Safari 11.1, macOS Mojave Safari 12.1, macOS Catalina Safari 13.1, Windows 10 IE11.900.18362.0. Unfortunately there are no tests for this feature detection, nor would it be easy to write one for the particular scenario where a macOS setting is required.

Fixes #14609.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(cdk/platform): rtl scroll axis incorrectly determined in Safari macOS" (#19830)

Issues.Title: docs: fix incorrect template reference to map marker
Issues.Body:
The readme file for google-maps serves as basic documentation for the
google-maps package. Currently it suggests an invalid template reference
since we switched from a component to a directive.

Directives do not provide the `$implicit` context, so we'd
need to use the explicit directive `exportAs` name.

Fixes #19807.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "docs: fix incorrect template reference to map marker" (#19826)

Issues.Title: help(CdkTable): Why are we always forcing rerendering all rows even when 1 column had changed
Issues.Body:
In my project we extensively use CdkTable and had recently stumbled upon performance issue. We are rendering 20 rows with 40 columns. When we dynamically add even 1 column the table instead of adding that one column rerenders all 20 rows with 41 columns. Is there a particular reason why are we not using difference approach just like we do with rendering additional rows?

Here is the method responsible for such a behaviour:
https://github.com/angular/components/blob/1106cb1ea7d07ce603e2afeb3a9e0e0f71d4e5db/src/cdk/table/table.ts#L786+L802
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "help(CdkTable): Why are we always forcing rerendering all rows even when 1 column had changed" (#19825)

Issues.Body:
#### Feature Description

Example can be found in this package >> https://www.npmjs.com/package/@angular-material-components/datetime-picker

in addition it would be nice to add slot to add my template

```
 <mat-datepicker #picker>

```

Issues.Title: docs-bug(COMPONENT): Textual improvements of the progress-bar documentation
Issues.Body:
#### Documentation Feedback

In the documentation on progress bars, a few times the description says "... where the user wants to indicate ..." but this is incorrect. The user does not want to indicate anything here. Also, the texts are gramatically incorrect and confusing.

https://material.angular.io/components/progress-bar/overview#buffer

- Current text: "Operations where the user wants to indicate some activity or loading from the server, use the buffer indicator."
- Suggestion: "Use the buffer indicator to indicate loading from the server in addition to the actual progress."

https://material.angular.io/components/progress-bar/overview#query

- Current text: "For situations where the user wants to indicate pre-loading (until the loading can actually be made), use the query indicator."
- Suggestion: "Use the query indicator to indicate pre-loading before the actual loading starts."

Thanks,
Peter
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "docs-bug(COMPONENT): Textual improvements of the progress-bar documentation" (#19817)
